column2: Thus spake Zarathustra.
column3: Thus spake Zarathustra.

column2: Once on a time, Zarathustra also cast his fancy beyond man, like all backworldsmen.
column3: Once on a time, Zarathustra also cast his fancy beyond man, like all backworldsmen.

column2: The work of a suffering and tortured God, did the world then seem to me.
column3: The work of a suffering and tortured God, did the world then seem to me.

column2: The dream--and diction--of a God, did the world then seem to me; coloured vapours before the eyes of a divinely dissatisfied one.
column3: The dream-and diction-of a God, did the world then seem to me; coloured vapours before the eyes of a divinely dissatisfied one.

column2: Good and evil, and joy and woe, and I and thou--coloured vapours did they seem to me before creative eyes.
column3: Good and evil, and joy and woe, and I and thou-coloured vapours did they seem to me before creative eyes.

column2: The creator wished to look away from himself,--thereupon he created the world.
column3: The creator wished to look away from himself,--thereupon he created the world.

column2: Intoxicating joy and self-forgetting, did the world once seem to me.
column3: Intoxicating joy and self forgetting, did the world once seem to me.

column2: This world, the eternally imperfect, an eternal contradiction's image and imperfect image--an intoxicating joy to its imperfect creator:--thus did the world once seem to me.
column3: This world, the eternally imperfect, an eternal contradiction's image and imperfect image-an intoxicating joy to its imperfect creator:--thus did the world once seem to me.

column2: Thus, once on a time, did I also cast my fancy beyond man, like all backworldsmen.
column3: Thus, once on a time, did I also cast my fancy beyond man, like all backworldsmen.

column2: Beyond man, forsooth?
column3: Beyond man, forsooth?

column2: Ah, ye brethren, that God whom I created was human work and human madness, like all the Gods!
column3: Ah, ye brethren, that God whom I created was human work and human madness, like all the Gods!

column2: A man was he, and only a poor fragment of a man and ego.
column3: A man was he, and only a poor fragment of a man and ego.

column2: And verily, it came not unto me from the beyond!
column3: And verily, it came not unto me from the beyond!

column2: What happened, my brethren?
column3: What happened, my brethren?

column2: I surpassed myself, the suffering one; I carried mine own ashes to the mountain; a brighter flame I contrived for myself.
column3: I surpassed myself, the suffering one; I carried mine own ashes to the mountain; a brighter flame I contrived for myself.

column2: And lo!
column3: And lo!

column2: Thereupon the phantom WITHDREW from me!
column3: Thereupon the phantom WITHDREW from me!

column2: To me the convalescent would it now be suffering and torment to believe in such phantoms: suffering would it now be to me, and humiliation.
column3: To me the convalescent would it now be suffering and torment to believe in such phantoms: suffering would it now be to me, and humiliation.

column2: Weariness, which seeketh to get to the ultimate with one leap, with a death-leap; a poor ignorant weariness, unwilling even to will any longer: that created all Gods and backworlds.
column3: Weariness, which seeketh to get to the ultimate with one leap, with a death leap; a poor ignorant weariness, unwilling even to will any longer: that created all Gods and backworlds.

column2: It was the body which despaired of the body--it groped with the fingers of the infatuated spirit at the ultimate walls.
column3: It was the body which despaired of the body-it groped with the fingers of the infatuated spirit at the ultimate walls.

column2: Believe me, my brethren!
column3: Believe me, my brethren!

column2: It was the body which despaired of the earth--it heard the bowels of existence speaking unto it.
column3: It was the body which despaired of the earth-it heard the bowels of existence speaking unto it.

column2: And then it sought to get through the ultimate walls with its head--and not with its head only--into "the other world."
column3: And then it sought to get through the ultimate walls with its head-and not with its head only-into "the other world."

column2: But that "other world" is well concealed from man, that dehumanised, inhuman world, which is a celestial naught; and the bowels of existence do not speak unto man, except as man.
column3: But that "other world" is well concealed from man, that dehumanised, inhuman world, which is a celestial naught; and the bowels of existence do not speak unto man, except as man.

column2: Verily, it is difficult to prove all being, and hard to make it speak. Tell me, ye brethren, is not the strangest of all things best proved?
column3: Verily, it is difficult to prove all being, and hard to make it speak. Tell me, ye brethren, is not the strangest of all things best proved?

column2: Yea, this ego, with its contradiction and perplexity, speaketh most uprightly of its being--this creating, willing, evaluing ego, which is the measure and value of things.
column3: Yea, this ego, with its contradiction and perplexity, speaketh most uprightly of its being-this creating, willing, evaluing ego, which is the measure and value of things.

column2: A new pride taught me mine ego, and that teach I unto men: no longer to thrust one's head into the sand of celestial things, but to carry it freely, a terrestrial head, which giveth meaning to the earth!
column3: A new pride taught me mine ego, and that teach I unto men: no longer to thrust one's head into the sand of celestial things, but to carry it freely, a terrestrial head, which giveth meaning to the earth!

column2: The sick and perishing--it was they who despised the body and the earth, and invented the heavenly world, and the redeeming blood-drops; but even those sweet and sad poisons they borrowed from the body and the earth!
column3: The sick and perishing-it was they who despised the body and the earth, and invented the heavenly world, and the redeeming blood drops; but even those sweet and sad poisons they borrowed from the body and the earth!

column2: From their misery they sought escape, and the stars were too remote for them.
column3: From their misery they sought escape, and the stars were too remote for them.

column2: Then they sighed: "O that there were heavenly paths by which to steal into another existence and into happiness!" Then they contrived for themselves their by-paths and bloody draughts!
column3: Then they sighed: "O that there were heavenly paths by which to steal into another existence and into happiness!" Then they contrived for themselves their by paths and bloody draughts!

column2: Beyond the sphere of their body and this earth they now fancied themselves transported, these ungrateful ones.
column3: Beyond the sphere of their body and this earth they now fancied themselves transported, these ungrateful ones.

column2: But to what did they owe the convulsion and rapture of their transport?
column3: But to what did they owe the convulsion and rapture of their transport?

column2: To their body and this earth.
column3: To their body and this earth.

column2: Gentle is Zarathustra to the sickly.
column3: Gentle is Zarathustra to the sickly.

column2: May they become convalescents and overcomers, and create higher bodies for themselves!
column3: May they become convalescents and overcomers, and create higher bodies for themselves!

column2: Neither is Zarathustra indignant at a convalescent who looketh tenderly on his delusions, and at midnight stealeth round the grave of his God; but sickness and a sick frame remain even in his tears.
column3: Neither is Zarathustra indignant at a convalescent who looketh tenderly on his delusions, and at midnight stealeth round the grave of his God; but sickness and a sick frame remain even in his tears.

column2: Many sickly ones have there always been among those who muse, and languish for God; violently they hate the discerning ones, and the latest of virtues, which is uprightness.
column3: Many sickly ones have there always been among those who muse, and languish for God; violently they hate the discerning ones, and the latest of virtues, which is uprightness.

column2: Backward they always gaze toward dark ages: then, indeed, were delusion and faith something different.
column3: Backward they always gaze toward dark ages: then, indeed, were delusion and faith something different.

column2: Raving of the reason was likeness to God, and doubt was sin.
column3: Raving of the reason was likeness to God, and doubt was sin.

column2: Too well do I know those godlike ones: they insist on being believed in, and that doubt is sin.
column3: Too well do I know those godlike ones: they insist on being believed in, and that doubt is sin.

column2: Too well, also, do I know what they themselves most believe in.
column3: Too well, also, do I know what they themselves most believe in.

column2: Verily, not in backworlds and redeeming blood-drops: but in the body do they also believe most; and their own body is for them the thing-in-itself.
column3: Verily, not in backworlds and redeeming blood drops: but in the body do they also believe most; and their own body is for them the thing in itself.

column2: But it is a sickly thing to them, and gladly would they get out of their skin.
column3: But it is a sickly thing to them, and gladly would they get out of their skin.

column2: Therefore hearken they to the preachers of death, and themselves preach backworlds.
column3: Therefore hearken they to the preachers of death, and themselves preach backworlds.

column2: Hearken rather, my brethren, to the voice of the healthy body; it is a more upright and pure voice.
column3: Hearken rather, my brethren, to the voice of the healthy body; it is a more upright and pure voice.

column2: More uprightly and purely speaketh the healthy body, perfect and square-built; and it speaketh of the meaning of the earth.--
column3: More uprightly and purely speaketh the healthy body, perfect and square built; and it speaketh of the meaning of the earth.--

column2: Thus spake Zarathustra.
column3: Thus spake Zarathustra.
